wiki.content: On “Savior”, Kendrick teams up with Sam Dew and Baby Keem to inform his listeners about the brokenness of society. The song comes directly after “Savior (Interlude),” which Baby Keem also plays a central role on. In the intro, Kendrick sets the tone by reminding those who look up to public figures that they are only human. Each verse tackles a different subject: in the first verse, he addresses a host of racial issues; in the second, he talks about COVID-19 and political correctness; and, in the third verse, he discusses his own flaws and struggles. Kendrick is well-known for his Christian faith, as evidenced by such songs as “YAH.” and “FEAR.” from April 2017’s DAMN.—which dropped on Good Friday, the day Christians commemorate Christ’s crucifixion. With this in mind, when Kendrick talks about the lack of a modern-day Messiah, we are instead pointed to his savior: Jesus Christ. River Tiber was sampled in this song and talked about that on Twitter. “Savior” reunites cousins Kendrick Lamar and Baby Keem, their previous collaborations include the two collaborative tracks on Baby Keem’s 2021 sophomore album, "The Melodic Blue", “family ties,” “range brothers,” as well as “vent,” although Kendrick is not formally credited on the song. The pair have collaborated on numerous other occasions during their careers, Baby Keem produced the instrumental used on Kendrick’s 2019 collaboration with Beyoncé, “NILE,” and is responsible for producing and co-writing several tracks on "Mr. Morale & The Big Steppers". The tracks “Die Hard” and “N95” off the album are both produced and written by Kendrick’s cousin. Although “Savior” is the first time Sam Dew has formally collaborated with both Keem and Kendrick, he also has numerous writing credits and vocal appearances on "Mr. Morale & The Big Steppers". Tracks such as “Rich Spirit,” “Worldwide Steppers” and “United in Grief” are only a handful of Dew’s contributions to the project. Read more on Last.fm.
